Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Geomagnetic Variability, Paleoenvironmental Change, and a Tuned Geologic Timescale from Pacific Eocene-Pleistocene Sediments from IODP Expeditions 320-321
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study will conduct paleomagnetic analyses of equatorial Pacific sediment cores spanning the Eocene through the Pleistocene collected during IODP expeditions 320 and 321. Using high resolution U-channel measurements, this project will produce a high resolution magnetostratigraphic record that could serve as a very important chronostratigraphic tool. The project will address five objectives: 1) refine the shipboard magnetostratigraphies, 2) generate continuous geomagnetic intensity and directional paleosecular variation records, 3) generate environmental magnetic records, 4) improve the Cenezoic geologic timescale, and 5) improve our understanding of the Pacific apparent polar wander.

Broader impacts: The project would support undergraduate and/or graduate students at the universities of all four PIs. The project also effectively capitalizes on a large investment previously made in an IODP expedition and further enhances the collaborations and exchange of information between several international members of the expedition and the IODP community. By developing such an important chronological tool that helps refine the geologic timescale and improves the geomagnetic intensity record, the project significantly impacts the earth sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goals of this project were accomplished by (1) determining the ages of the sedimentary sections cored by refining the shipboard magnetostratigraphies and resolving brief polarity subchrons and geomagnetic excursions; (2) generating long continuous relative geomagnetic intensity (RPI) and directional paleosecular variation (PSV) records to better understand how the geomagnetic field works; (3) constructing high?resolution environmental magnetic records to understand environmental processes active during the Eocene and Oligocene; (4) improving the geologic timescale over much of the Cenozoic (the past 66 million years) by combining information in the physical and magnetic properties data with the magnetostratigraphy and biostratigraphy constraints; and (5) determining the past position of the Pacific Plate using paleolatitudes estimated from paleomagnetic data we collected. Our results have been shared as they were obtained with all the Expedition 320 and 321 scientists to ensure speedy and complete transfer of the age data, which are critical to all the other climatic and environmental objectives of the Expedition 320/321 drilling program. We have completed seven publications related to this project so far including published papers in Nature and in the Proceedings of the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program; two in press papers, one in a Special Publication of the Geological Society of London and the other in G-cubed (Geochemisty, Geophysics, and Geosystems); and three submitted papers, one to G-cubed and the other two to Earth and Planetary Science Letters. Results were also presented as talks and posters at multiple international science meeting, with associated published abstracts. One public lecture was given at University of California-Davis (UCD) entitled '50 Million Years of Earth History From a Pacific Equatorial Age Transect (PEAT) Cored by the Refurbished JOIDES Resolution'.

The grant also provided geoscience training and development for two undergraduate students at UCD: Holly Motts and Melissa Lum. Holly has since accepted a position with the U.S. Geological Survey and Melissa will attend graduate school. As part of the collaboration, I have also worked with Carl Richter’s (a co-PI) graduate student, Emily Palmer (Guidry), who visited the UC Davis lab for several weeks, during which time I helped train her on how to measure and process the very large number of data being generated. Emily has successfully completed here Masters of Science studies and has since accepted a job with a petroleum company.
